context: Within 1–2 h following exposure, organic solvents induce skin inflammation that is characterized by increased blood flow, vascular permeability, leukocyte infiltration into the skin, and epidermal degeneration (Steele and Wilhelm, 1966, 1970). For this study, we chose m-xylene as a representative VOC that is an industrial cleansing agent used in paints, thinners, and fuels. In skin, application of xylene results in plasma extravasation from the skin vasculature, leukocyte infiltration, epidermal degeneration, and increasing levels of oxidative species and low molecular-weight DNA levels (Von Burg, 1982; Iyadomi et al., 1998; Rogers et al., 2001). Dermal absorption of m-xylene leads to increased blood and tissue concentrations of m-xylene (Engström et al., 1978; McDougal et al., 1990; Morgan et al., 1991; Kezic et al., 2000). The purpose of this study was to develop an in vitro exposure method that could ultimately be used with a biologically-based model to evaluate the toxicity and irritancy potential of VOCs. We needed to develop a system that maintains a constant chemical dose and enables calculation of the VOC concentration in the cultured cells. Knowing the chemical concentration in the target cells during in vitro exposures is necessary to characterize the relationship between the chemical concentration and observed biological response(s).
